quotes: Sadik joined the UN Population Fund in 1971.
UN Secretary-General Javier Pérez de Cuéllar appointed her to succeed him, in 1987, thus becoming the first woman to head one of the United Nations' major voluntarily-funded programmes.
In June 1990, the Secretary-General of the United Nations appointed Sadik Secretary-General of the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD), 1994.
In June 1990, the Secretary-General of the United Nations appointed Sadik Secretary-General of the International Conference on Population and Development (ICPD), 1994.
Sadik was the President of the Society for International Development (SID) for the period 1994–1997.
Sadik married Azhar Sadik, a Pakistani army officer died earlier in 2011.
Nafis Sadik died of congestive heart failure on 14 August 2022 in the United States, at the age of 92.

organizations.name: UN Population Fund
quotes: Sadik joined the UN Population Fund in 1971.

After her retirement from the United Nations Population Fund, she served on several boards of directors and advisory panels of non-profit organizations and research institutions in the area of population control.

quotes: She was a member of the Board of Governors of the Foundation for Human Development, and a member of the South Asian Commission on the Asian Challenge.

organizations.name: German Foundation for World Population
quotes: After her retirement from the United Nations Population Fund, she served on several boards of directors and advisory panels of non-profit organizations and research institutions in the area of population control including on the Advisor Board for the German Foundation for World Population.

organizations.name: Population Action International
quotes: Sadik was an Emeritus Member of Population Action International.

roles.title: Executive Director of UNFPA
quotes: Shortly after the sudden death of the UNFPA Executive Director, Rafael Salas, UN Secretary-General Javier Pérez de Cuéllar appointed her to succeed him, in 1987, thus becoming the first woman to head one of the United Nations' major voluntarily-funded programmes.

This was particularly important for population policies and programmes in the Third World and developing countries, where her strategy for providing females with education and the tools to control their own fertility has influenced the global birthrate.
